title: Fundamentals of IT System Administration
description: This module covers essential concepts, tools, and best practices for IT system administrators to maintain secure and efficient computing environments.
content:
1. Introduction to System Administration

  • nitoring: Using tools (e.g., Nagios, SolarWinds) to track system health and preempt failures.


2. Essential SysAdmin Tools

  • Remote Access: SSH (Linux/macOS) and RDP (Windows) for remote management.
  • Automation: Scripting (PowerShell, Bash) to streamline repetitive tasks.
  • Virtualization: VMware or Hyper-V for resource-efficient server deployment.


3. Common Challenges & Solutions

  • Downtime Prevention: RAID configurations for redundancy; load balancers for traffic distribution.
  • Security Threats: Regular audits, multi-factor authentication (MFA), and employee training to combat phishing.
  • Scalability: Cloud integration (AWS/Azure) for flexible resource allocation.


4. Best Practices

  • Document all changes to systems and networks.
  • Follow the Principle of Least Privilege (PoLP)


System administrators (sysadmins) maintain an organization’s IT infrastructure, ensuring reliability, security, and performance. Key responsibilities include:

  • User Management: Creating, modifying, and disabling accounts via directory services (e.g., Active Directory, LDAP).
  • Security: Implementing firewalls, patches, and access controls to protect against breaches.
  • Backup & Recovery: Scheduling backups and testing disaster recovery plans.

caseStudy.title: Server Outage Crisis
caseStudy.content: The primary file server at XYZ Corporation crashed at 11:30 PM, affecting 200+ employees. The last backup was 24 hours old, and critical financial data from today's transactions hasn't been backed up. As the on-call system admin, you must restore services while minimizing data loss.

questions.question: What would be your first three actions in this situation?
questions.answer:
1. Diagnose the cause of crash (hardware failure? corruption?).

2. Notify stakeholders about expected downtime.

3. Attempt data recovery from backup or temporary solutions.

questions.question: How would you prevent this situation in the future?
questions.answer: Implement real-time backups, server monitoring alerts, and a documented disaster recovery plan.

questions.question: If hardware diagnostics show a failed RAID controller but the drives are intact, what would be your recovery approach?
questions.answer:
1. Replace the RAID controller with an identical model,

2. Rebuild the RAID array using the existing drives,

3. Validate data integrity before bringing the server back online.
